channel.title: Chris KY FUNG's Blog
channel.description: Feel free to bookmark this to keep an eye on my project updates

item.title: Organize Your Instapaper Library With No Code Using Carrot2
item.description:
The Challenge: Too Many Bookmarks, No System

You‚Äôve been using Instapaper for months or even years. Articles about various subjects, for example, career, personal development, productivity tips, programming tutorials, and random news stories‚Äîall sitting in one giant ‚ÄúArticles‚Äù folder. When you want to dive deep into a topic, you‚Äôre scrolling through hundreds of unrelated links.

Sound familiar?

The problem isn‚Äôt that Instapaper is bad. It‚Äôs that manually organizing 300+ articles into folders and tags takes forever. What if you could just upload your bookmarks and let a smart tool automatically group them into topics?

That‚Äôs where Carrot2 comes in.

Carrot2 is an open-source tool that automatically organizes documents into thematic clusters. No coding required. No complex machine learning knowledge. Just upload your data, click a button, and watch the software discover the hidden themes in your reading collection. Think of it as an intelligent librarian who reads all your bookmarks and organizes them into neat thematic piles.

In this tutorial, I‚Äôll show you how to use Carrot2 with your Instapaper exports to create a visual map of your reading interests.

Skip table of contents
Table of Contents
  • The Challenge: Too Many Bookmarks, No System
  • What is Carrot2?
  • Why This Matters for Your Reading List
  • Part 1: Prepare Your Data
  • Part 2: Access Carrot2
    • Option A: Use the Online Demo (Quickest)
    • Option B: Install Locally (Maximum Privacy)
  • Part 3: Upload Your Bookmarks
  • Part 4: Explore Your Results
  • Part 5: Choosing the Right Algorithm
  • Part 6: Refine and Export
    • Interpreting Weak Results
    • Export Your Results
  • Why Carrot2 Beats Manual Organization
  • Constraints and Limitations
  • Troubleshooting: When Results Seem Wrong
  • Next Steps
  • Final Thoughts
  • Resources

What is Carrot2?

Think of Carrot2 as a ‚Äúclustering engine‚Äù for documents. Here‚Äôs what that means in plain English:

You give it a collection of articles or text documents. Carrot2 reads through them all and automatically groups similar articles into meaningful categories and labels them with short, descriptive phrases. It then creates beautiful, interactive visualizations so you can explore your clusters, drill down into specific groups, and understand the shape of your knowledge.

Unlike traditional folder-based organization (where you manually decide categories), Carrot2 discovers patterns in your data. It‚Äôs fast, runs in your web browser, and requires zero programming knowledge.

Key facts:

  • Completely free and open-source (no ads, no paywalls)
  • Works entirely in your browser (no scary command line)
  • Designed by researchers specifically for organizing documents
  • Can run locally on your computer (your data never leaves your machine)
  • Works perfectly with Instapaper export data

Why This Matters for Your Reading List

When you cluster your Instapaper library, you gain:

  • Quick overview: See at a glance what topics dominate your reading habits
  • Efficient browsing: Find related articles on a subject without endless scrolling
  • Pattern discovery: Realize ‚ÄúOh, I really do read a lot about productivity and AI‚Äù
  • Smarter organization: Use the discovered clusters to better organize your bookmarks in the future
  • Time saved: Stop manually categorizing‚Äîlet the algorithm do the work

Part 1: Prepare Your Data

First, export your Instapaper bookmarks. If you haven‚Äôt already, install Instapaper Scraper:

pip install instapaper-scraper

Then export to CSV format:

instapaper-scraper --format csv --output instapaper_bookmarks.csv

Open your CSV file in Excel, Google Sheets, or any spreadsheet application. You should see columns like:

id title url
1234567890 Introduction to Neural Networks https://‚Ä¶
1234567891 React Hooks Tutorial https://‚Ä¶
1234567892 Notion for Second Brains https://‚Ä¶

Alternatively, export to JSON format:

instapaper-scraper --format json --output instapaper_bookmarks.json

Either way, you end up with a data file (CSV or JSON) containing your bookmarks. This is exactly what Carrot2 wants to see. If your file looks good, you‚Äôre ready to move to the next step.

Important note: If your bookmark titles contain non-Latin characters (CJK and others like Greek), use JSON instead of CSV due to a file reading bug in Carrot2 (as observed in v4.8.3 while writing this post).

Part 2: Access Carrot2

You have two options here as well:

Option A: Use the Online Demo (Quickest)

Visit the Carrot2 Clustering Workbench at the official demo site:

üîó https://search.carrot2.org/#/workbench

This is the fastest way to try clustering without installing anything. Just visit the site in any modern browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge).

Important note: The online demo has a limitation‚Äîyour data is temporarily transferred to the Carrot2 server for processing. None of it is permanently stored, but if you‚Äôre concerned about privacy, use Option B instead.

Option B: Install Locally (Maximum Privacy)

If you prefer to keep your reading data on your own machine:

Requirements:

  • Java 11 or later (free, available at java.com)

Installation:

  1. Download the latest Carrot2 release from GitHub: https://github.com/carrot2/carrot2/releases
  2. Extract the downloaded file to a folder on your computer
  3. Open the dcs folder and run the dcs script (on Mac/Linux) or dcs.cmd (on Windows)
  4. Open your browser and go to http://localhost:8080

That‚Äôs it. Carrot2 is now running on your machine, and all your data stays private.

Tips: To change the port number, use the --port command line parameter, e.g.:

dcs --port 1234

Part 3: Upload Your Bookmarks

Whether you‚Äôre using the online demo or local installation, the interface looks the same:

Step 1: Select Data Source

  • In the ‚ÄúData source‚Äù dropdown at the top left, choose ‚ÄúLocal file‚Äù

Step 2: Upload Your CSV

  • Click the file upload area and select your instapaper_bookmarks.csv file
  • You can also drag and drop the file directly

Step 3: Choose Fields to Cluster

  • Carrot2 automatically detects text fields in your CSV
  • Recommended: enable ‚Äútitle‚Äù and ‚Äúdescription‚Äù (if available)
  • Disable numerical fields like ‚Äúid‚Äù and ‚Äúurl‚Äù

Step 4: Click ‚ÄúCluster‚Äù

  • The software analyzes your data and generates clusters

This usually takes just a few seconds for collections under 1,000 bookmarks. Sit back and let the magic happen.

Part 4: Explore Your Results

After clustering completes, you‚Äôll see your bookmarks organized into groups. Each cluster has:

  • A descriptive label (e.g., ‚ÄúPython‚Äù, ‚ÄúMachine Learning‚Äù, ‚ÄúData Science‚Äù)
  • The article count (how many bookmarks are in this group)
  • A list of documents that belong to that cluster

Carrot2 gives you multiple views of the same data:

  1. List View (Best for Reading Details) Shows clusters as a simple list. Click any cluster to see the bookmarks it contains. Scroll through articles in a cluster to read titles, descriptions, and click links back to the original articles. This is the most straightforward view and best for exploring your data carefully.

  2. Treemap View (Best for Spotting Proportions) A visual representation where each cluster is a rectangle. Larger rectangles = more bookmarks in that cluster. At a glance, you can see which topics dominate your library. For example, if the ‚ÄúPython‚Äù rectangle is huge but ‚ÄúMachine Learning‚Äù is tiny, you know where your reading priorities lie.

  3. Pie Chart View (Best for Interactive Exploration) A simple pie chart showing what percentage of your bookmarks fall into each cluster. Great for understanding the shape of your interests.

To switch between views, look for the tabs or icons at the top of the results panel‚Äîusually labeled ‚ÄúList‚Äù, ‚ÄúTreemap‚Äù, and ‚ÄúPie Chart‚Äù.

Part 5: Choosing the Right Algorithm

Behind the scenes, Carrot2 uses different mathematical approaches to clustering. You don‚Äôt need to understand the technical details, but here‚Äôs what you need to know:

Algorithm Best For Speed Label Quality
Lingo High-quality, descriptive labels Medium ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
STC Very fast clustering, large collections Very Fast ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
K-Means Simple, non-overlapping clusters Very Fast ‚≠ê‚≠ê

For Instapaper bookmarks, we recommend Lingo‚Äîit produces the most descriptive cluster labels, which makes it easier to understand what each group of articles is about.

To change the algorithm: look for the ‚ÄúAlgorithm‚Äù dropdown in the left panel, select your choice, and click ‚ÄúCluster‚Äù again.

Part 6: Refine and Export

Interpreting Weak Results

If your clusters don‚Äôt look quite right‚Äîfor example, articles seem randomly grouped or labels don‚Äôt make sense‚Äîhere are common fixes:

  1. Mixed-language content? Select ‚ÄúEnglish‚Äù (or your language) from the language dropdown to improve label accuracy
  2. Clusters too broad? Try the STC algorithm for more fine-grained grouping
  3. Not enough clusters? The default settings work for most cases, but if you want to experiment, try adjusting clustering parameters through the left-side panel

Export Your Results

Once you‚Äôre happy with your clusters, you have options:

  • Screenshot: Use your browser‚Äôs screenshot tool to save a visual of the pie chart or treemap
  • Copy cluster labels: Manually note the cluster labels and use them to organize your Instapaper folders

  • Create a report: Export the cluster list and document assignments (check if there‚Äôs an export button in the interface)

    1. Click the Export button (top right of results panel)
    2. Choose your format:
      • Excel (easiest to work with)
      • CSV (import to Google Sheets)
      • JSON (for advanced use)

    The export includes:

    • NEW: A ‚ÄúCluster‚Äù column showing which group each article belongs to
    • All your original columns (id, title, url, etc.)

    Now you have a spreadsheet that looks like this:

    Cluster id title url
    Machine Learning 1234567890 Introduction to Neural Networks https://‚Ä¶
    Web Development 1234567891 React Hooks Tutorial https://‚Ä¶
    Productivity 1234567892 Notion for Second Brains https://‚Ä¶

    What can you do with this?

    • Import into Notion or Obsidian and organize by cluster
    • Use as a reading roadmap (‚ÄúThis week, I‚Äôll focus on the Machine Learning cluster‚Äù)
    • Share curated topic lists with friends
    • Identify knowledge gaps (are there clusters you thought would be bigger?)

Why Carrot2 Beats Manual Organization

Task Manual (Folders/Tags) Carrot2
Time to organize 300 articles 2-3 hours 5 minutes
Discover unexpected themes Unlikely Common
Re-organize with new logic Hours of work 30 seconds (re-cluster)
Visualize your knowledge Impossible Beautiful & interactive
Keep data private Yes Yes (if local)
Learn new topics Your job Carrot2‚Äôs job

Constraints and Limitations

Be aware of these practical limits:

  • Best for 100‚Äì1,000 bookmarks: Carrot2 is optimized for small-to-medium collections. If you have 10,000+ articles, clustering will be slower and may use significant memory
  • Lingo algorithm slower for large collections: If you‚Äôre clustering more than 1,000 items and it feels slow, switch to the STC algorithm
  • Quality depends on data quality: Bookmarks with very short or vague titles may not cluster as well as those with descriptive ones

Troubleshooting: When Results Seem Wrong

  • ‚ÄúOne cluster is huge, others are tiny‚Äù ‚Üí Your bookmarks might naturally cluster that way. Or try a different algorithm (STC instead of Lingo).

  • ‚ÄúArticles in the same cluster don‚Äôt seem related‚Äù ‚Üí Maybe they share some keywords but aren‚Äôt semantically related. Try re-clustering with different parameters or check if those articles have messy/generic titles.

  • ‚ÄúCarrot2 won‚Äôt upload my file‚Äù ‚Üí Make sure your file is valid CSV or Excel format. If stuck, use the online demo instead of local installation.

  • ‚ÄúResults are too granular (100 tiny clusters)‚Äù ‚Üí Try the Lingo algorithm and adjust the parameter panel. Some algorithms create more clusters by default.

  • ‚ÄúI want to change the cluster labels‚Äù ‚Üí You can‚Äôt directly edit cluster labels in Carrot2, but you can export the results and manually rename clusters in Excel if needed.

Next Steps

Once you‚Äôve discovered your clusters, here‚Äôs what you can do:

  1. Reorganize Instapaper: Create folders based on cluster labels and move bookmarks accordingly
  2. Set reading goals: Pick a cluster you want to focus on this week (e.g., ‚ÄúMachine Learning‚Äù) and work through those articles
  3. Share your patterns: The cluster breakdown tells you a lot about your interests‚Äîit can inform what you read next
  4. Combine with other tools: Use the cluster information to feed a personal knowledge management system (Obsidian, Roam Research, Notion)

Final Thoughts

Carrot2 transforms a flat list of bookmarks into an organized, discoverable knowledge landscape. By automating the boring categorization work, you free yourself to focus on what matters: actually reading and learning from your saved articles.

The best part? It‚Äôs completely free, surprisingly fast, and works right in your browser. No advanced technical skills required‚Äîjust your curiosity and your reading list.

Have you tried clustering your bookmarks? Drop a comment below and share what interesting patterns you discovered in your own reading habits!

Resources

  • Carrot2 Official Site
  • Carrot2 Online Demo
  • Carrot2 GitHub Repository
  • Java Downloads (if installing locally)
  • Carrot2 - Wikipedia
  • Carrot2 Clustering Workbench Documentation
  • Algorithm Comparison
  • Lingo3G or Carrot2? | Carrot Search
  • Carrot2 Performance Guidelines
  • Personalized Library Book Recommendations Using K-Means Clustering and Association Rules ‚Äì Journal of Scientometric Research
  • Clustering Snippets With Carrot2 - Index Data
  • Analysis and Comparison of Web Document Clustering Algorithms with Lingo ‚Äì IJERT

item.title: InstapaperScraper v1.1: Now with JSON, SQLite Exports, and a Better CLI
item.description:
It‚Äôs time for a big update! I‚Äôm excited to announce the release of InstapaperScraper v1.1, a significant upgrade that makes the tool more powerful, flexible, and easier to use.

The original version was a simple script to help users export their bookmarks to CSV. This new version builds on that foundation, adding more export options and a much-improved user experience, while remaining a reliable tool for those who prefer not to use an API.

Let‚Äôs dive into what‚Äôs new.

Skip table of contents
Table of Contents
  • What‚Äôs New in v1.1?
  • Getting Started with v1.1
  • Your Data, Your Rules
  • Contribute & Stay Updated

What‚Äôs New in v1.1?

This release focuses on flexibility, robustness, and a more modern developer experience.

  • Multiple Export Formats: You asked for it, you got it! In addition to CSV, you can now export your bookmarks to JSON and SQLite. This gives you the power to use your data in a wide range of applications, from data analysis pipelines to custom web apps.

  • TOML for Configuration: We‚Äôve moved away from .env files to config.toml. This provides a standardized, more expressive way to configure folder settings and other options.

  • Powerful CLI: The script now features a command-line interface (CLI) powered by argparse. You can specify folders, output and provides clear options to select export formats and manage authentication.

Getting Started with v1.1

Getting started is simple. The tool is now a proper Python package available on PyPI.

  1. Install the Package:

     pip install instapaper-scraper

  2. Configure (Optional): To scrape specific folders, create a config.toml file. You can place it in your user config directory (~/.config/instapaper-scraper/config.toml) or the working directory.

     # Example config.toml
 [[folders]]
 key = "ml"
 id = "1234567"
 slug = "machine-learning"
 output_filename = "ml-articles.json"

  3. Run the Scraper: The script will securely prompt for your credentials on the first run and save your session.

     # Export to the default CSV format
 instapaper-scraper

 # Export to JSON
 instapaper-scraper --format json

 # Export a specific folder to a custom SQLite database
 instapaper-scraper --folder ml --format sqlite --output my_ml_articles.db

    You can also pass your credentials directly via the command line if you prefer.

Your Data, Your Rules

With these new export options, you have more control than ever:

  • Analyze with SQLite: Run complex SQL queries on your bookmarks to uncover reading patterns.
  • Integrate with JSON: Easily feed your data into other applications or web services.
  • Keep it Simple with CSV: Stick with the classic format for quick analysis in any spreadsheet program.

Contribute & Stay Updated

InstapaperScraper is an open-source project. If you find it useful, please consider starring it on GitHub! Your contributions are also welcome‚Äîfeel free to report issues, suggest features, or submit pull requests.

Happy reading, and may your data bring you as much joy as the articles you‚Äôve saved!

item.title: Get a FREE, Automated YouTube Subscriber Tracker in Google Sheets
item.description:
TL;DR:

  • What it is: A simple, open-source script for Google Sheets (Google Apps Script).
  • What it does: Automatically pulls new subscriber names and their channel links directly from your YouTube notification emails.
  • The Best Part: It archives the data in a sheet AND moves the processed emails to the trash, decluttering your Gmail inbox while you sleep.
  • The Outcome: A permanent, one-click engagement list for building loyal fans.

Why You Need This Free Script

For New YouTubers & Growing Channels:

We‚Äôve all been there: The dopamine hit from a ‚Äù[New User] has subscribed to you on YouTube!‚Äù email. But that feeling fades instantly as the email gets buried in your inbox.

If you are just checking YouTube Studio for your total count, you are treating your audience like a metric. But for a growing channel, your first followers are the people you need to impress, engage with, and thank.

Your first 1,000 subscribers are your founding members. They deserve a personalized thank-you. Stop relying on fleeting email notifications and start building a real community roster.

This is where the youtube-subscriber-spreadsheet-apps-script helps you build a real connection and a permanent record of your channel‚Äôs history‚Äîall for free.

The Bootstrap Method: How We Get the Data for Free

Instead of wrestling with complex YouTube APIs, this project uses a smarter, simpler method: we leverage the notification emails already sitting in your Gmail.

This solution is entirely self-contained within Google‚Äôs free services (Sheets + Gmail).

The Automated Workflow (Set It and Forget It)

The script executes this highly efficient four-step workflow automatically:

  1. Search & Retrieve: It uses the powerful built-in Gmail service to search for all new emails matching the specific YouTube notification subject line.
  2. Extract the Data: The script quickly scans the raw email content. It uses clever data extraction techniques (Regular Expressions) to pull out the most important details: the subscriber‚Äôs name and their channel link.
  3. Log & Archive: The extracted Date, Subscriber Name, and Attribution Link are then logged as new entries in your Google Sheet.
  4. Clean Up: Once the data is safely logged, the script moves the corresponding email to the Trash, ensuring the same notification is never processed twice and achieving instant inbox decluttering.

Why This System Changes the Game

This system is built for efficiency and community engagement:

  • Declutter Your Gmail Inbox: For multi-channel creators, the deluge of notifications is a nightmare. This system processes and archives them automatically, reserving your inbox for real conversations.
  • Zero Hosting Cost: It runs inside Google‚Äôs free infrastructure, meaning no server bills or maintenance‚Äîever.
  • A ‚ÄúSet It and Forget It‚Äù System: After the initial 15-minute setup, you set a time-driven trigger in the Apps Script dashboard. The script logs your new public subscribers while you sleep. No manual execution needed.

The Elegant Output: Your New Roster

We skip the raw email data and deliver a clean, actionable log focused on building relationships:

1. The Date üìÖ

Actionable Insight: See precisely when growth happened to correlate it with specific content or external events.

2. The Subscriber (Hyperlinked) üîó

The One-Click Engagement Hack: The script uses a sheet formula to combine the name and the channel link (=HYPERLINK(...)). This gives you a one-click engagement tool: Click the name, land on their channel, and leave a thank-you comment. You just turned a passive subscriber into a loyal superfan.

3. Subscribed Channel üì∫

Multi-Channel Utility: If you manage multiple channels (e.g., a main channel and a clips channel), this provides instant clarity on which asset is driving the growth‚Äîall aggregated in one central log.

Wrap-Up: Start Building Your Community Today

Stop letting the most valuable names in your community disappear into your email trash. This free, open-source script gives you the perfect tool to nurture your early supporters, spot collaboration opportunities, and keep your inbox clean.

üëâ Get the Script on GitHub

If you found this tool useful, give the repo a Star ‚≠êÔ∏è on GitHub. It helps other creators find this free solution!

item.title: Supercharge Your Learning: A Free Userscript to Track Google Skills Progress
item.description:
Looking for an older version?

This post is for v3.0 and later, which supports the new Google Cloud Skills Boost platform. If you are looking for the archived post for the old Qwiklabs platform (v2.x), you can find it here: Userscript for Qwiklabs v2.0 (Archived).

Important Update

Google has renamed ‚ÄúGoogle Cloud Skills Boost‚Äù to ‚ÄúGoogle Skills‚Äù and moved its domain from cloudskillsboost.google to skills.google since October 2025. Please update the Lab Tracker userscript to v3.1.0 or later to ensure compatibility with the new domain. For more details on the change, see this related post from Google‚Äôs Blog.

Google Skills (formerly Qwiklabs) is a fantastic platform for gaining hands-on experience with Google Cloud. With hundreds of labs and courses, it‚Äôs a go-to resource for anyone serious about advancing their cloud skills.

But if you‚Äôre an active user like me, you‚Äôve probably faced a common challenge: it‚Äôs hard to remember which labs you‚Äôve already finished. To solve this, I created the Qwiklabs Lab Completion Tracker, a free userscript designed to streamline your learning journey.

This simple script runs in your browser with an extension like Tampermonkey (available for Chrome, Firefox, Edge, and others). It enhances the Google Skills website by adding clear visual indicators, so you can see your progress at a glance.

üöÄ Key Features

  • Completion Markers: Automatically adds a green checkmark () next to completed labs and courses, so you never have to guess what you‚Äôve already done.
  • ‚ÄúNew‚Äù Badges: Instantly spot new labs and courses with an orange ‚ÄúNew‚Äù badge () that have been added since your last sync.
  • One-Click Sync: Manually trigger a database update with the sync button () on your Progress page.

üì∏ Screenshots

The script adds helpful visual cues across the Google Skills website.

Sync and Manage Your Data

Managing your progress is simple. Just visit your Progress page and use the one-click sync button to update your local database with your latest completions.

Changelog

For a detailed list of updates and new features, check out the Version History page.

Future Plans

This script is actively maintained, and I‚Äôm always looking for ways to improve it. You can follow the project‚Äôs progress, report bugs, or suggest new features on the GitHub Issues page.

See Also:

  • Learning Google Cloud Platform on Qwiklabs: Learning Map, Assistive Tool and Tips

item.title: Qwiklabs Lab Completion Tracker - Version History
item.description:
This page provides a detailed version history for the Qwiklabs Lab Completion Tracker userscript. It documents the evolution of the script, from its initial release to the latest updates, detailing new features, improvements, and bug fixes designed to help users track their learning progress on Google Cloud Skills Boost (formerly Qwiklabs).

Back to the main post

v3.0.0 - Migration to Google Cloud Skills Boost üöÄ

2025-10-04

This major release marks a significant milestone, migrating the entire script to support the platform‚Äôs rebranding from qwiklabs.com to the new Google Cloud Skills Boost (cloudskillsboost.google). This was a critical update to ensure continued functionality for all users. Beyond the migration, this version introduced several key enhancements. The script now automatically creates records for new activities, improving tracking on catalog search results. Under the hood, significant refactoring was done to improve robustness, readability, and security by avoiding innerHTML and centralizing ID extraction.

  • Breaking Change: Full migration from qwiklabs.com to cloudskillsboost.google.
  • Features:
    • Automatically create records for unregistered activities.
    • Improve activity tracking for catalog search results.
  • Fixes:
    • Improve robustness with null checks for DOM elements.
    • Improve main function‚Äôs error logging.
  • Refactoring:
    • Improve script robustness, readability, and security by avoiding innerHTML.
    • Centralize ID extraction using named groups in the router.

v2.1.0 - Enhanced Profile Page and Routing

2021-10-14

This release enhanced the profile page with several key features. Pagination was added to allow browsing of the entire activity history. Visual cues, such as warning icons for unrecognized labs and a red background for failed ones, were introduced to make it easier to identify items requiring attention.

The main function was also refactored to use a more robust routing system, improving code maintainability and structure.

v2.0.7 - Styling and Bug Fixes

2021-10-13

This maintenance release included styling adjustments to align with a new activity card design on Qwiklabs. It also addressed several bugs related to the database update feature to improve its reliability.

v2.0 - Revamp for New Qwiklabs Web Design üöÅ

2021-09-30

Following a major platform redesign by Qwiklabs in late September 2021, this version was released with a significant code rewrite to ensure compatibility with the new user interface. This update restored all core features of the tracker.

v1.0 - Fix the Change in My Learning URL

2021-09-18

  • Replaced /my_learning with /profile/activity.
  • Changed the CSS selector and Regular Expression to look up the total number of activities.
  • Do not support pages with a URL starting with /my_learning.

v0.5.5 - Improved Activity Name Recognition

2021-05-04

To address parsing issues with activity names containing special characters, this release improved data integrity by using the unique lab/quest ID as the primary key for database updates, rather than relying on the activity name.

v0.5.4 - Fix the Change in My Learning Layout

2021-04-09

  • Added a quick link to view all My Learning Activity results
  • Revised the way to update the database records with the new format of learning activity data

v0.5.2 & v0.5.3 - Adapting to UI Changes

These minor updates were released to maintain compatibility with Qwiklabs‚Äô evolving design. They included the removal of code for deprecated pages and adjustments to correctly parse the new Catalog and My Learning Activity table layouts.

v0.5.1

2020-06-14

A one-click sync button was introduced to improve user experience. This feature allows for an instant update of all lab and quest statuses in the local database, eliminating the need for manual checks.

v0.5.0

This foundational update migrated data storage from a simple markup-based system to IndexedDB, resulting in more efficient and scalable data handling. A significant portion of the codebase was also refactored to use modern async/await syntax, improving readability and maintainability.

For v0.4.8 or Earlier

Early versions of the script relied on a manually maintained list of completed labs stored within the userscript. The primary feature was a green check-circle () added to completed items on catalog pages to simplify progress tracking.

v0.4.8 - Support Tracking ‚ÄúHome‚Äù and ‚ÄúMy Learning‚Äù Pages

2020-06-06

Tracking support was extended to the Home and My Learning pages. This version also introduced NEW badges and yellow highlights for activities not yet present in the database, making it easier to identify new content.

v0.4.5

2020-05-20

This version introduced visual highlights for completed items to improve visibility. Annotations were extended to the ‚ÄúYour Favorites‚Äù section, and colored backgrounds were added to tables on the ‚ÄúCompleted Courses‚Äù and ‚ÄúCompleted Labs‚Äù pages for easier scanning. To help distinguish between different activity types, a purple highlight was added for game records.

item.title: Securely Self-Host n8n with Docker, Traefik, and Cloudflare
item.description:
I‚Äôm a huge fan of n8n, the powerful workflow automation tool. While self-hosting n8n offers great flexibility, I found the initial setup process could be complex and time-consuming. I wanted a simple, secure, and repeatable way to deploy my own n8n instance. That‚Äôs why I created n8n-stack.

I‚Äôm excited to share it with you today!

Skip table of contents
Table of Contents
  • What is n8n-stack?
  • Why Self-Host n8n with This Stack?
  • Key Features of n8n-stack
  • Getting Started with Your Secure n8n Instance
  • Let Me Know What You Think
  • Take Control of Your Automation
  • References

What is n8n-stack?

n8n-stack (officially n8n-traefik-cloudflared-stack) is a production-ready set of configuration files to help you self-host n8n using Docker or Podman. It comes with Traefik as a reverse proxy and is secured by Cloudflare Zero Trust, giving you a private and secure n8n environment.

The project is based on an excellent tutorial by Kjetil Furas, but I‚Äôve added my own tweaks and enhancements to make it even more robust and user-friendly for a seamless n8n self-hosting experience.

The stack includes:

  • n8n: The star of the show for all your automation needs.
  • Traefik: A modern reverse proxy to handle web traffic efficiently.
  • Cloudflare Tunnel: Securely exposes your n8n instance to the internet without opening firewall ports, thanks to Cloudflare Zero Trust.

Why Self-Host n8n with This Stack?

  • Enhanced Security: By using Cloudflare Tunnel, you don‚Äôt expose your server directly to the internet. All traffic is routed through Cloudflare‚Äôs secure network.
  • Simplified Management: The docker-compose.yml files are pre-configured for a quick start.
  • Cost-Effective: Self-hosting can be cheaper than paid plans, especially if you already have a server.
  • Full Control: You have complete control over your data, workflows, and the n8n environment.

Key Features of n8n-stack

  • Docker and Podman Ready: Includes compose files for both Docker and rootless Podman, so you can use your preferred container engine.
  • Security Hardened: The default configuration is enhanced for better security, such as using a file-based provider for Traefik.
  • Simple Backup and Restore: A handy script is included to help you back up and restore your n8n data with ease.
  • Clear Documentation: Comprehensive documentation is available in the /docs directory to guide you through every step.
  • Pinned Versions: n8n and traefik image versions are pinned to ensure stable and predictable deployments.

Getting Started with Your Secure n8n Instance

I‚Äôve tried to make it as simple as possible to get up and running:

  1. Clone the repository:

     git clone https://github.com/chriskyfung/n8n-traefik-cloudflared-stack.git
 cd n8n-traefik-cloudflared-stack
  2. Follow the setup instructions: The README.md contains all the details for the initial configuration.
  3. Choose your container engine: Head over to the /docs directory and follow the specific guide for either Docker or Podman.

Let Me Know What You Think

I built n8n-stack to solve my own n8n self-hosting challenges, and I hope it can be useful to others in the community. I‚Äôd love for you to check it out on GitHub, give it a try, and share your feedback.

Check out the n8n-stack repository on GitHub

I‚Äôm always open to feedback and contributions, so feel free to open an issue or a pull request!

Take Control of Your Automation

Embarking on the self-hosting journey for your workflow automation can seem complex, but it doesn‚Äôt have to be a daunting task. With n8n-stack, you are equipped with a clear, secure, and production-ready path to unlock the full potential of n8n on your own terms. This project was born from the desire to eliminate the initial setup hurdles, providing a robust environment with Docker, Traefik, and Cloudflare right out of the box.

This stack is more than just a collection of configuration files; it‚Äôs a launchpad designed to get you up and running quickly, so you can focus on what truly matters: building powerful, creative automations that solve real-world problems. The power to innovate is now firmly in your hands. Dive in, explore the possibilities, and start your n8n journey today.

Happy Automating! üöÄ

References

  • Self-Host n8n with Cloudflare Zero Trust and Docker by Kjetil Furas
  • n8n Documentation
  • Traefik Documentation
  • Cloudflare Zero Trust Documentation
  • Podman Documentation
  • Docker Documentation

item.title: InstapaperScraper: Export Your Bookmarks to CSV Effortlessly
item.description:
IMPORTANT

This post describes an early version of InstapaperScraper. The project has since been updated to v1.1, which offers more features, and is much more reliable.

Please read the new announcement post for more information.

In today‚Äôs digital age, managing saved Instapaper articles can be overwhelming, especially for free plan users who lack a search feature. Obtaining API keys for Instapaper APIs can also be time-consuming.

Say hello to InstapaperScraper‚Äîa lightweight Python script designed to simplify the process. With InstapaperScraper, you can scrape bookmarks from your Instapaper account and export them as neatly formatted CSV data‚Äîall without needing an API key.

Skip table of contents
Table of Contents
  • What Is InstapaperScraper?
  • Getting Started
  • Unlocking Data-Driven Insights
  • Contribute & Stay Updated

What Is InstapaperScraper?

InstapaperScraper is a simple Python tool for retrieving and organizing Instapaper bookmarks. Key features include:

  • Comprehensive Bookmark Scraping: Efficiently organize bookmarks from your homepage or specific folders, with pagination support to ensure no bookmarks are missed.

  • CSV Export: InstapaperScraper formats bookmark metadata‚Äîpage number, ID, title, and URL‚Äîinto CSV output, making it easy to import and analyze in tools like Excel or Google Sheets.

  • Effortless Configuration: Set up a .env file with your Instapaper credentials and optional folder settings to start scraping immediately.

Getting Started

Setting up InstapaperScraper is quick and straightforward. Follow these steps:

  1. Clone the Repository Download the project from GitHub.

  2. Install Dependencies Use the provided requirements.txt to install all necessary Python libraries:

    pip install -r requirements.txt

  3. Configure Your Environment Create a .env file in the project root with the following:

    INSTAPAPER_USERNAME=your_username
INSTAPAPER_PASSWORD=your_password
ENABLE_FOLDER_MODE=true  # Optional: enable this to scrape a specific folder
FOLDER_ID_AND_SLUG=your_folder_id/your_folder_slug  # Required if folder mode is enabled

  4. Run the Scraper Export your bookmarks to CSV by running:

  python scrape.py > bookmarks.csv

With this setup, you can quickly back up your Instapaper bookmarks locally.

Unlocking Data-Driven Insights

The CSV output from InstapaperScraper opens up exciting possibilities for data analysis and visualization:

  • Filter by Page Index: Use text editors or Microsoft Excel to find the page number or bookmark ID of a specific bookmark, enabling you to locate its pagination or full-text view.

  • Analyze Reading Patterns: Track your reading habits over time to identify trends in interests or productivity.

  • Categorize Bookmarks: Organize bookmarks by topic or source to gain insights into your preferred content types.

  • Set Goals and Automate Recommendations: Integrate bookmark data with other tools to create personalized reading goals, recommendations, or automated content curation.

Contribute & Stay Updated

InstapaperScraper is an open-source project on GitHub (chriskyfung/InstapaperScraper) that welcomes contributions. Share your ideas, join discussions, or submit pull requests to help advance the project.

Happy scraping, and may your bookmarks always be in order!

item.title: Fix Netlify CLI & Node Task List `ntl` Conflict on Windows with Volta
item.description:
If you‚Äôre a web developer hosting your projects on Netlify, chances are the Netlify CLI (netlify-cli) is one of your must-have tools for streamline deployments, configuring site settings, and debugging issues‚Äîall right from your terminal. At the same time, Node Task List (ntl) is a fantastic utlity that scans your package.json and creates an interactive menu of npm scripts. With NTL, you can easily launch tasks like starting a server or running builds in just a few clicks, saving you time and effort.

The catch is that both packages attempt to register the same executable name, ntl. When installed globally via npm, this results in a naming conflict and produces installation errors.

Common Errors

On Linux with NVM:

# Terminal

$ npm install -g ntl
npm error code EEXIST
npm error path /home/user/.nvm/versions/node/v20.17.0/bin/ntl
npm error EEXIST: file already exists
npm error File exists: /home/user/.nvm/versions/node/v20.17.0/bin/ntl
npm error Remove the existing file and try again, or run npm
npm error with --force to overwrite files recklessly.

Luckily, fixing the conflict on Linux is straightforward if you‚Äôre using the Node version manager NVM. Simply install netlify-cli first, then force the installation of ntl using the --force option to overwrite the conflicting executable.

On Windows with Volta:

# PowerShell

$ npm install -g ntl --force
Volta error: Executable 'ntl' is already installed by netlify-cli

Please remove netlify-cli before installing ntl

For Windows users especially who rely on Volta as their Node version manager, the issue is a bit trickier. Volta doesn‚Äôt allow conflicting executables, so forcing the installation of ntl won‚Äôt resolve the problem.

In this guide, we‚Äôll walk you through the steps to resolve the naming conflict on Windows, ensuring that both tools can coexist peacefully and letting you enjoy the best of both worlds in your development workflow.

Step-by-Step Guide to Fix the Conflict

1. Uninstall Node Task List (if already installed)

To ensure there are no lingering conflicts, begin by uninstalling any global installation of Node Task List:

npm uninstall -g ntl

2. Install Netlify CLI

Next, install the Netlify CLI globally. This sets up the ntl executable for Netlify:

npm install -g netlify-cli

3. Verify the Netlify CLI Installation

Check that Netlify CLI is properly installed by running:

volta which ntl

You should see an output similar to:

C:\Users\<User Name>\AppData\Local\Volta\tools\image\packages\netlify-cli\ntl

4. Modify Volta‚Äôs User Binaries Configuration

Open File Explorer and navigate to:

C:\Users\<User Name>\AppData\Local\Volta\tools\user\bins\

5. Remove the Conflicting Registration File

In the bins folder, locate and delete the file named ntl.json. Removing this file clears the conflicting registration for the ntl command.

6. Reinstall Node Task List

With the conflicting file removed, reinstall Node Task List globally:

npm install -g ntl

This command registers Node Task List with its own executable path without interfering with Netlify CLI.

7. Verify Both Installations Are Working Separately

Finally, ensure both tools are correctly configured by checking their respective executable paths:

volta which ntl
volta which netlify

The outputs should point to different locations, for example:

  • Node Task List: ...\Volta\tools\image\packages\ntl\ntl
  • Netlify CLI: ...\Volta\tools\image\packages\netlify-cli\netlify

Now you‚Äôre all set! You can use the ntl command to run Node Task List tasks, while the netlify command will work with the Netlify CLI‚Äîwithout any conflicts.

Conclusion

By following these steps, you resolve the executable naming conflict between Node Task List and Netlify CLI on a Windows machine with Volta. This solution is perfect for Netlify developers who want to maintain a smooth, efficient workflow without installation hassles.

If you‚Äôre interested in more tips, be sure to check out our blog for additional resources.

Happy coding!

Additional Resources

  • Get started with Netlify CLI | Netlify Docs
  • Top 10 Netlify CLI Commands - DEV Community

item.title: Unlock IFTTT: Build a Dynamic Database with Google Sheets
item.description:
IFTTT (If This Then That), a leading automation platform supporting over 900 apps and services, simplifies cross-platform tasks in everyday life. However, its lack of native database integration forces users to rely on Google Sheets as a workaround for data storage, creating challenges for data-driven workflows like content scheduling or random task assignment.

This guide will show you how to use IFTTT‚Äôs ‚ÄúFilter Code‚Äù to transform Google Sheets into a lightweight NoSQL database, capable of storing thousands of JSON-formatted entries. This bridges the gap between ‚Äútriggers‚Äù and ‚Äúactions‚Äù with streamlined data processing.

Skip table of contents
Table of Contents
  • Learning Objectives
  • Practical Use Cases
  • Step-by-Step Guide
    • Prerequisites
    • Step 1: Format Your Google Sheets Data
    • Step 2: Create an IFTTT Applet
    • Step 3: Test and Debug
  • Key Takeaways
  • Final Thoughts
  • Additional Resources

Learning Objectives

Before diving in, it‚Äôs important to note that IFTTT isn‚Äôt the ideal automation tool for complex data workflows. Platforms like Zapier, Make, n8n, and Microsoft Power Automate are better suited for such tasks. This guide focuses on extending IFTTT‚Äôs capabilities and unlocking greater value for users already familiar with IFTTT‚Äôs interface.

By the end of this tutorial, you‚Äôll be able to:

  1. Overcome IFTTT‚Äôs Limits: Fully utilize the query allowance (i.e. single-row A-Z columns, up to 30,000 characters per cell) to bypass bottlenecks in data processing.
  2. Optimize Data Storage: Compress thousands of structured data entries into JSON format within a single row, turning your spreadsheet into a functional database.
  3. Streamline Data Handling: Extract content for random selection or conditional filtering and push results to designated platforms such as email, notifications, or social media.

Practical Use Cases

Here are some creative ways to apply this setup:

  • Content Creation: Pull blog topics or daily writing prompts automatically.
  • Digital Marketing: Schedule social media posts from a curated database to maintain brand or product exposure.
  • Education: Share quiz questions or motivational quotes to boost engagement.
  • Everyday Life: Automate recipe suggestions or fitness challenges for variety.

Step-by-Step Guide

Prerequisites

  • An IFTTT Pro+ Subscription (required for Queries and Filter Code features).
  • A Google Sheets Document (formatted data as described below).

Step 1: Format Your Google Sheets Data

Organize your data as comma-separated JSON objects within cells. For example:

{"id":"1","quote":"Success is a lousy teacher. It seduces smart people into thinking they can‚Äôt lose.","author":"Bill Gates","hashtag":"#MotivationalQuotes"},
{"id":"2","quote":"I don‚Äôt spend my time pontificating about high-concept things; I spend my time solving engineering and manufacturing problems.","author":"Elon Musk","hashtag":"#CareerWisdom"},
{"id":"3","quote":"Quality is more important than quantity. One home run is much better than two doubles.","author":"Steve Jobs","hashtag":"#LifePhilosophy"}

Key points:

  • Spread datasets across columns A-Z in a single row.
  • Ensure no cell exceeds 30,000 characters.
  • Validate your JSON syntax with tools like JSONLint.

Step 2: Create an IFTTT Applet

  1. Select a Trigger
    • Testing Phase: Use Button Widget for manual execution.
    • Routine Operations: Use Date & Time for scheduled triggers.
    • Advanced Options: Integrate other apps for event-based triggers or use Webhooks for API calls.
  2. Set Up a Google Sheets Query
    • Choose Current values of a row (read current values from a specific row).
    • Provide your spreadsheet‚Äôs shareable link and specify the row to query (e.g., Row 2).
  3. Add Actions (Supports multiple actions)
    • Notifications: Add Email > Send me an email to receive updates directly.
    • Dynamic updates: Add Google Sheets > Update cell in spreadsheet for advanced customization.

  4. Add Filter Code Paste this example TypeScript snippet into the filter editor for random selection:

    // Retrieve data from columns A-Z
const cellValues: { [key: string]: string } = GoogleSheets.cellValuesInRow[0];
   
// Initialize an empty array to store parsed JSON data
let dataset: Record<string, any>[] = [];
   
// Parse JSON strings
for (const key in cellValues) {
  if (/^Column/.test(key)) {
    const jsonChunks: string[] = cellValues[key].match(/\{.*?\}/g) || [];
    jsonChunks.forEach(chunk => {
      dataset.push(JSON.parse(chunk));
    });
  }
}
   
// Random selection
const randomIndex = Math.floor(Math.random() * dataset.length);
const selectedData = dataset[randomIndex] || { error: "No valid data" };
   
// Output result
Email.sendMeEmail.setBody(`Today‚Äôs Recommendation: ${selectedData.content || 'No data'}`);

    Optional Enhancements:

    • Add conditional statements for dynamic filtering.

    • Perform real-time updates by modifying a cell with the Update cell in spreadsheet action. For example:

      // Retrieve the value of ColumnE
let newCellValue = cellValues['ColumnE'];
     
// Example: Convert the value to uppercase (customize logic as needed)
newCellValue = newCellValue.toUpperCase();
     
// Update the specified cell in the spreadsheet (e.g., B5)
GoogleSheets.updateCellInSpreadsheet.setCell('B5');
GoogleSheets.updateCellInSpreadsheet.setValue(newCellValue);

Step 3: Test and Debug

  • Use your chosen trigger to test the applet and observe the execution results.
  • Check whether the data updates in the spreadsheet as intended.
  • Track error messages via IFTTT Activity Log and make adjustments.

Key Takeaways

By leveraging Filter Code and Google Sheets, you can unlock a new level of flexibility for IFTTT workflows. Despite limitations like single-row queries, column constraints (A‚ÄìZ), and a 30,000-character cell limit, compressing data into JSON fragments and reassembling it opens up endless possibilities.

What creative possibilities come to mind for you? If you‚Äôre already an IFTTT Pro+ user, consider these applications:

  • Daily Recipe Rotation: Keep meals fresh with automated suggestions.
  • Smart Task Assignment: Allocate tasks based on team performance data.
  • Weather-Based Alerts: Combine real-time weather data with personalized reminders.

If you haven‚Äôt joined IFTTT yet, sign up via this referral link to enjoy 10% off and start creating your automations today!

Final Thoughts

This tutorial isn‚Äôt just about technical workarounds‚Äîit‚Äôs about reimagining the possibilities of tools. Just as DeepSeek creatively overcomes hardware constraints to develop groundbreaking AI technology, we too can push the boundaries of what‚Äôs achievable through clever design and innovative thinking.

Let‚Äôs break boundaries with creativity! Feel free to share your unique ideas in the comments section and explore more creative applications together!

Additional Resources

  • IFTTT Plans at a glance ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • What is a query? ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • Building with filter code ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • How to add filter code ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • Filter code generators ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • Example Applets using queries and filter code ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • Parsing JSON body with filter code ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • Can I make my Applets run only at certain times? ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • Get random strings from an array with no duplicates ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • How to create multi-action Applets ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • IFTTT Service Rate Limits ‚Äì IFTTT Help Center
  • How to Use IFTTT With Google Sheets | Envato Tuts+

item.title: Fixing Old Emails in Your Git History: A Beginner's Guide
item.description:
Git is a powerful version control system that acts like a diary for your code. Every change you make gets recorded in what‚Äôs called a commit history. But what if you realize some of your commits are tied to an outdated email address? Maybe you used a school email that‚Äôs no longer active, or your personal email for work projects and want to tidy up your digital footprint. Let‚Äôs learn how to fix that! In this guide, you‚Äôll learn how to update your email address across all commits, using the mighty git filter-branch command.

Skip table of contents
Table of Contents
  • Understanding Git Identity
  • The Problem: Ghosts of Emails Past
  • The Magic Command: git filter-branch
    • Variables (Your ‚ÄúBefore‚Äù and ‚ÄúAfter‚Äù)
    • The ‚ÄúFind and Replace‚Äù Logic
    • Scope (Where to Fix)
  • Step-by-Step: Safely Rewriting History
    • ‚ö†Ô∏è Step 0: Backup Your Repository
    • Step 1: Run the Script
    • Step 2: Force-Push the Changes
  • Caveats and Helpful Tips
  • Why Bother? A Lesson Beyond the Code
  • Final Thoughts
  • References

Understanding Git Identity

When you make a commit, Git records two key pieces of identity information:

  • Author: The person who originally wrote the code.
  • Committer: The person who added the code to the repository (often the same as the author).

If either of these fields uses an out-of-date email address, it can lead to confusion‚Äîespecially if you want your work to reflect who you are today.

The Problem: Ghosts of Emails Past

Imagine your coding journey is like a scrapbook. Each commit is a snapshot of your progress. You set up Git with your shiny new GitHub email, but when you push code, your commits are still linked to old_school_email@university.edu‚Äîan account you can‚Äôt even access anymore! It might confuse future readers (or even recruiters) checking your portfolio. Updating your commit history helps you:

  • Present a Professional Image: Your Git history becomes a polished record of your growth.
  • Improve Traceability: Linking commits to your current email makes it easier to track contributions.

This happened to me when I tried to share code from my postgraduate projects. My commits were tied to an ancient email, making my contributions invisible on GitHub. Worse, collaborators couldn‚Äôt recognize my work.

The solution? Rewriting Git history to update old emails. Let‚Äôs break down how to do this safely.

The Magic Command: git filter-branch

To magically update your old commits, we use a shell script with git filter-branch‚ÄîGit‚Äôs built-in ‚Äúhistory editor.‚Äù Think of it as a ‚Äúfind and replace‚Äù feature for your entire Git history that has the old email with your updated details.

While powerful, it‚Äôs not beginner-friendly‚Äîso follow closely! Here‚Äôs the script to update emails and names in all commits:

git filter-branch --env-filter '  
WRONG_EMAIL="old.email@example.com"
NEW_NAME="Your New Name"
NEW_EMAIL="new.email@newdomain.com"

if [ "$GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL" = "$WRONG_EMAIL" ]; then  
    export GIT_AUTHOR_NAME="$NEW_NAME"  
    export GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL="$NEW_EMAIL"  
fi

if [ "$GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL" = "$WRONG_EMAIL" ]; then  
    export GIT_COMMITTER_NAME="$NEW_NAME"  
    export GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL="$NEW_EMAIL"  
fi
' --tag-name-filter cat -- --branches --tags

Let‚Äôs break it down:

  1. Variables (Your ‚ÄúBefore‚Äù and ‚ÄúAfter‚Äù)

    At the start of the script, you assign your details:

    • WRONG_EMAIL: The email you want to replace (e.g., an old school address).
    • NEW_NAME and NEW_EMAIL: Your current name and email (like your GitHub credentials).

    Replace these placeholders with your actual values.

  2. The ‚ÄúFind and Replace‚Äù Logic

    The script checks whether the commit‚Äôs author or committer email matches your old email. If it does, it replaces the name and email with your new ones. In plain terms:

    • If this commit was made with the wrong email, update it.

  3. Scope (Where to Fix)

    Finally, the options --tag-name-filter cat -- --branches --tags ensure that every branch and tag in your repository is checked and updated if needed.

Step-by-Step: Safely Rewriting History

‚ö†Ô∏è Step 0: Backup Your Repository

Rewriting history is a big change! Make sure you have a backup (or clone) of your repository before running the script.

You can clone a copy of your repo:

git clone --mirror your-repo-url backup-folder

Step 1: Run the Script

  1. Open Git Bash or Terminal.
  2. Navigate to your repository (cd your-repo). Note: Replace your-repo with your actual repository name.
  3. Paste the script, replacing WRONG_EMAIL, NEW_NAME, and NEW_EMAIL with your details.

Step 2: Force-Push the Changes

Since history has been rewritten, you need to force-push the changes to your remote repository:

git push origin --force --all
git push origin --force --tags

Note: If you work on a team, coordinate with your teammates before force-pushing, as this can disrupt others‚Äô work.

Caveats and Helpful Tips

  • Working in a Team: Rewriting history changes commit IDs (hashes). Make sure everyone on your project is aware and ready to adjust their local copies.

  • Large Repositories: The git filter-branch command can be slow on big projects. For faster results, consider using BFG Repo-Cleaner.

  • Modern Alternatives: The Git community now often recommends using git filter-repo for such tasks. While this guide focuses on filter-branch (because of its wide use and educational value), it‚Äôs worth exploring newer tools as you advance.

  • Prevent Future Headaches: Configure Git to use your correct email globally.

    git config --global user.name "Your Name"  
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"

  • Check Your Work: After running the script, verify a commit‚Äôs details with

    git log --format="%an <%ae>, %cn <%ce>"

Why Bother? A Lesson Beyond the Code

Fixing your Git history isn‚Äôt just a technical task‚Äîit‚Äôs a lesson in attention to detail, responsibility, and self-improvement. Your Git history is like your academic portfolio; keeping it accurate reflects your growth as a programmer. Plus, you‚Äôre learning a technique that could prove useful when dealing with sensitive data or accidental mistakes in the future.

Final Thoughts

Rewriting Git history isn‚Äôt something you‚Äôll need to do every day. It might seem intimidating at first, but with careful steps and a clear understanding, it‚Äôs a powerful skill. By updating your commit emails, you‚Äôre not only tidying up your past work but also setting up a professional foundation for your future projects.

So, take a deep breath, back up your work, and give it a try. With each commit, you are fine-tuning your development story‚Äîa story that is uniquely yours!

Happy coding!

References

  1. How to Change Git Commit Author Information for All Commits: A Complete Guide | by Gokul | Medium

  2. command line - Git commits are not getting linked with my GitHub account - Stack Overflow

  3. Git Official Documentation on filter-branch
    The official Git documentation explaining the filter-branch command.

  4. Git commits are not getting linked with my GitHub account

  5. Protecting Your Code: How to Prevent and Fix Sensitive Data Exposure on GitHub | by ALameer Ashraf | Medium
